item.title: Bagging and Boosting in Human learning
item.description:
Just a funny thought: education in humanities follows bagging trees, education in natural sciences follows boosting. Here is why..

Think about this..

Humanities:

  • Read a book. Understand precisely what an author is saying, understand his/her model/view of reality/world
    -> Fit a tree to get a simple model. Build a fully grown tree (don’t prune)
  • Read another book. Get another view of reality. Ideally, this shall be done without any filters of perception which may have been learned from the 1st book
    -> Fit another tree
  • Read many more books
    -> Fit many trees
  • Make up your mind based on conglomerations of all those ideas and some other experiences
    -> Use an aggregation of trees as a final model

In both cases, there is a high variance of views from book to book (from model to model), and ideally low bias (deep understanding of every book). Aggregation helps reduce variance in both cases.

Natural sciences (for example Physics)

  • Read one book/take intro class. Understand it as much as you can on the first run
    -> fit shallow tree
  • Address what you did not understand from the first run. Try to understand those things which are still not clear
    -> fit another shallow tree on the residuals
  • Continue the refinement of the knowledge
    -> fit many more shallow trees, every time on residuals of previous models

In this case, every new iteration never (almost) makes understanding (model) learned (obtained) on previous iterations wrong, and mostly fine tunes those.

item.title: Advanced classes for stress reduction?
item.description:
Usually, perception is that the more advanced is the school and curriculum, the more stressed students are. Is this really the case?

First, let me define advanced: advance means a more complex, having more inter-connections, and thus triggering interest (given a sufficient skillset).

And let us concentrate on the situation when we have generally strong students.

Often, when schools are attempting to accommodate demand (from parents and bored students?) for higher standards of education, they introduce into programs more AP classes oriented for test taking. Classes, which will tell a kid who s/he is: A-grade student, B-grade student, etc. Classes that make students “run over material” instead of enjoying it. This creates a lot of stress. One can find research papers addressing stress level in schools, for example this.

Compare this with advanced classes:

  • Classes are taught by teachers who have in-depth professional knowledge and active interest in their area
  • Students are presented with an opportunity to go as deep as they can into complicated topics
  • Not every student will go equally deep, which is expected and normal
  • There is a certain expectation to get an A, but material covers much more than that so that every student can find a challenge for him/her self
  • I call this approach “No student left bored” (in contrast with famous “no student left behind”)
  • There is no clear way to compare yourself with others - because in any complicated area there are many ways to get better in something: while one student is improving one skill, another is improving another. There is no need to compare in this case: every student knows that his/her classmates know something better than s/he, but this is true for this student as well
  • Open-ended assignments without ‘one correct answer’ allow students to grow and get better relative to themselves a day before
  • Self-assessment becomes very important in this case. And in fact, is one of the goals of this approach. In contrast, the traditional approach forces students to look for external validation of their knowledge and skills
  • There is generally almost no way to fail
  • It is an interesting and challenging task to help students to develop their internal motivation. Use of a grade, in this case, has a fairly limited power

And there is also authentic research, which opens even more opportunities for advancing curriculum in every high school, aiming to help students learn about the world around them.

item.title: Teaching Data Science at a High School
item.description:
For two years I am teaching a Data Science class at a High School. Here I would like to share my experience and observations.

I started mentoring high school student research projects in Data Science 3 years ago, and this lead to a full scale 1 year class of Data Science. The class was taught at The Princeton International School of Mathematics and Science (PRISMS) - a small private school with exceptional students and research program for students. More about why doing research at high school makes sense and why it beneficial to students you can find here.

Class organization

Class format

  • Monday (40 minutes) - work on Shiny (1st semester)
  • Tue (90 min) - work on material: theory, exercises, practical examples, etc.
  • Thu (90 min) - work on a class projects (independent by each student, and 1 joint project)

Material distribution

Semester 1 - Data Exploration and Communication

The first thing I figured is that data exploration education takes time… I am using the whole semester to go over the book “R for Data Science”, where students learn to load data, explore and modify it using dplyr, plot data using ggplot2. The exercises in the book are just great!

On top of that once a week we spend time to implement some data analysis in R Shiny. This is extremely important for students to be able to make a completed project they can show to others. R Shiny puts abstract data exploration into a context of real world use by other people.

Git. Important. Really important. Students learn to use Git/GitHub independently and in group. We use both internal R studio’s Git interface and SourceTree (no bash).

To summarize, we do cover:

  • Data exploration and plotting following “R for Data Science”
  • Careful reading of errors produced by R. Looking for solutions online
  • Use of internal R help, packages vignettes and documentation
  • Learning new tools/packages independently
  • Shiny
  • Git and GitHub
  • Mentioning on how to use SQL if needed
  • Students make an independent and a group project
  • getting data by API (twitter)

Semester 2 - Machine Learning

In the second semester we move to machine learning and follow the book Introduction to Statistical Learning. We cover all the topics in the book. In the first chapters exercises are quite useful. However later, we move to use caret for most of the machine learning work.

To summarize, things covered are:

  • machine learning following Introduction to Statistical Learning book
  • caret package for machine learning
  • text mining
  • getting data by API (twitter)
  • Big data (basic examples and intro only): Spark (sparklyr), H2o.ai with R, deep learning
  • students make independent machine learning projects.

Tests

Every test is a small project students have to do. I usually give some general points students shall address in their data exploration or ML algorithm.

Tests are a perfect time to introduce new tools as well. As this way students are forced to learn them and at the same time learning to learn new tools on their own.
For example, students can be asked to work with dates/times and advised to use lubridate package. Or for a machine learning test, students can be given a task with text, accompanied by an initial introduction to a text-mining approaches/packages.

Tests often take a form of take-home-tests and can last anywhere between 1 and 7 days. The tests are submitted using GitHub.

Why R?

Why did I choose to use R for the class (and not Python, Mathematica, MATLAB…)?

The first obvious reason to choose R vs Mathematica/MATLAB is that it is free and open source. It is also easier to work with than let say Mathematica.

R has tons of packages that are easy to install, which allow to do almost anything.

Python package dependencies can be hard to manage. It can be OK for yourself, but when you have many students and you have to deal with installation problems which differ among platforms, the choice is clear - R just works on different platforms (most of the time :) )

And, I personally, like R, especially tidyverse universe of packages. R is built around data analysis, and focuses students on that!

Is there a place for Data Science in a High School?

The valid question actually… Why bother? Why not to focus student on more traditional classes, or give him/her to take one more AP?

4 Quadrants of Science education

A science education curriculum in a high school (Physics, Chemistry, Biology, …) is often focuses on theory. However, in real science there are at least 3 main parts: theory, experiment, and computer(numerical) simulations. And in order to present science to students in a right light, all of them should be covered in parallel (if possible). Data analysis traditionally was included into an experiment. However, the modern tools available make this area much wider and much more powerful than before. Now we can even build new type of models - ML models, in addition to theoretical models, and computer simulation models. (I do address computer simulations in another post here)

Thus, I strongly believe modern education in science should include the following 4 parts - 4 quadrants of science if you will. Such education will allow students to enrich their experience in any science they do. Students can perform better, reproducible data analysis, can do better clearer plots, will communicate better, and may find many more new ways to get something useful out of the data.

Data Science naturally forces open ended thinking

High school students learn new tools fast. It is not an issue at all to teach students “how” to use R and various packages. At the same time Data Science class provides a perfect platform to teach students to address the following:

  • how to formulate a question
  • which questions are meaningful
  • why do you do this or this action with data
  • why would you want to have this or this plot
  • how do you make a clear message
  • generally, “why” and “what” instead of a simple “how” - the question generally found in open ended tasks

Thus, there is a lot of time spend in a classroom to have discussions of such sort. It is of a paramount importance. This is one of the reasons making Data Science class such a good fit for a high school - it naturally forces kids to think independently on open ended tasks!

Outcomes

  • It is not a big deal for students to learn to code in R.
  • Generally, after the class students get much more confident to address open ended problems.
  • They learn to “figure out things” instead of asking for help (or even worse getting stuck) for every small detail.
  • At the same time, they learn to formulate good question when they actually need help. Students get a practice in making a “complete project”, which is presentable to the public and self-explanatory (in an ideal case).
  • Invited speakers can help students to see a beauty and potential of this new field. We were fortunate that Dr. Hadley Wickham accepted an invitation to give a remote talk. The talk did inspire students!
  • Students learn tools which they can apply (and they actually do) in other disciplines (especially in research projects). Examples include:
    • Cellphone tower data analysis
    • Astrophysics data
    • Electron microscope (SEM) image segmentation
    • Atomic force microscope (AFM) image analysis
    • Analysis of data obtained from a school-launched satellite
    • Visualization of genomic data
    • Analysis of text in a literature class

Projects examples

Group project

  • Renewable Energy exploration. Big Data Challenge:
    Shiny app, code on GitHub, Report in PDF

Class projects

  • Television show “Produce 101” seasons 1 & 2 data analysis: Report and Shiny App

  • The Quality of National Top Universities in Each State: Shiny app

Students’ research projects

  • Automating Reconstruction of Focused Ion Beam Current Density Distribution
    poster presented at FIBSEM meeting on March, 2017 (X. Li, S. Samsonau, E. Chang, V. Ray)
    Poster at professional meeting: Click for poster and an interactive application
    Code is not published yet - work in progress

  • Application of data science in tourism
    1st Place in Behavioral and Social Science at Mercer County Fair (link to results)
    Code is not published yet - work in progress

  • Correlation between emotional factors and the stock market
    Click for report, poster, code

  • Detecting fraud in election by statistical method
    Click for report and code

P.S. When data science shines

It is actually often the case, that most interesting data projects come from applying data science tools/methodology to an area where a student has an extensive knowledge, or at least has a profound interest. High school is a perfect place for students to learn data science tools and apply them, to whatever area they like!

item.title: Experimental labs with computer simulations
item.description:
While teaching laboratories for calculus-based Physics I figured out there is no teaching curriculum available which would combine actual experiments with computer (or also called numerical) simulations. So, I developed a sequence of 7 lab modules to implement exactly that.

Motivation

Computer simulations are now everywhere. Complexity of many real system does not allow to obtain a model written through analytic equations. In such situations numerical simulations provide a good (if not the only one) way to do address them.

Computer simulations allow people to perform weather forecasting, understand dynamics of star clusters, enhance particle physics research, allow to perform simulations of chemical interactions, as well as address many other systems.

So… why don’t we teach students to use simulations?

Description

The developed curriculum is composed from modules - each module uses both simulations and experiments to address a phenomena under study, and lasts for 3 weeks (21 weeks total for the whole set).

Wolfram Mathematica was chosen as a language for computer because it provides an easy to understand, follow (and modify) way to perform fairly good numerical simulations without a need of teaching students a full scale programming class.

Topics are:

  • Motion with a drag
  • Pendulum with an arbitrary amplitude
  • Magnus effect
  • Centripetal force acting on a pendulum
  • A ball rolling from paths of various shapes
  • Doppler shift and Fourier transformation
  • Equipotential lines.

Students generally only have a task setup by a teacher and some “starter code”. They have to develop an experiment and perform it by themselves. They also have to write the full simulation code and then compare experiment results with simulations.

This set was taught for two years in a calculus-based Physics Class in the following settings: 40 minutes once a week of class time (plus time allocated by students for work outside of classroom), 3 weeks per module. Most students went through advanced open-ended algebra-based labs the year before and were ready to work with open ended tasks.

More details

  • preprint on arxiv.org
  • code on GitHub

item.title: Essentials of Data Science (with R)
item.description:
There is a lot of information on Data Science on Internet. On this page I summarize the most essential things you would need to know to start working on real projects. The rest you can figure out on the way. This page is intentionally short (relativelly).

Books

  • R for Data Science
  • An Introduction to Statistical Learning
  • Data Science for Business

Tools, Installation and updating

  • installr package

    • for updating R to a newer version (from RGui do installr::updateR())
    • installing Rtools, git, ImageMagick, etc. Link

  • devtools package for installation of packages from github repositories directly

Interactive dashboards

  • R Shiny
  • R Shiny Gallery
  • R Shiny themes

Cheatsheets

  • dplyr and tidyr, ggplot, shiny sheet 1, shiny sheet 2, regular expressions

Databases

  • sqlzoo, sql

Working with medium data

  • If data can still fit in RAM of local machine, but slow to process with dplyr, a package data.table can provide a faster alternative
    • vignettes

Working with Big data (located in cluster)

  • sparklyr: R interface for Apache Spark
  • rsparkling: Sparkling Water (H2O) Machine Learning, including deep learning
  • R with Hadoop
  • Visualize Large Data

Text mining in R

  • tm package
  • Text Mining with R (book)

Plotting libraries

  • ggplot2 - see R for Data Science. There are many extentions for ggplot2. Some of them are here:
    • gridExtra to allign plots
    • ggbio - can be usefull in order to allign several plots (instead of gridExtra)
    • ggmap to make plots with geographical maps
    • ggpubr - modified ggplot2 for publication ready plots
  • plotly - makes ggplot2 interactive
  • ggvis - interactive plots (behind the scenes, interactive plots are built with shiny)
  • dygraph - R interface to the dygraphs JavaScript charting library. It provides rich facilities for charting time-series data in R
  • Visualize Large Data
  • color palletes in R

Books with Rmarkdown

  • https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/

Websites with Rmarkdown

Static sites (no need of databases, use of wordpress, etc.). Host for free on GitHub pages

  • https://www.rstudio.com/resources/webinars/introducing-blogdown/
  • https://slides.yihui.name/2017-rstudio-webinar-blogdown-Yihui-Xie.html
  • themes for hugo (a static site generator used by blogdown package)
    • find the one you like on this site https://themes.gohugo.io/
    • press Download - it should open a github address (if it is not GitHub it is ok..)
    • use this to install blogdown::install_theme(“user/repo”). It it is not on GitHub speicify hostname
    • fine tune the theme
    • host on GitHub pages or better in netfly
  • If you want to edit directly online, you can use this free service - cloudcannon. Also static webistes.

Additional Recommended Packages/triks

  • magick and EBImage - all kinds of image transformation, combination, animation, etc.
  • postr - making posters in R
  • profvis - profile the code: see which part of code runs longer
  • Adv. shiny tricks https://github.com/daattali/advanced-shiny
  • rMouse - control mouse
  • use Vectorize function to turn any function to a vectorized form
    sinv <- Vectorize(sin); sinv(matrix(1:25, ncol = 5))

Generally interesting resources

  • https://www.reddit.com/r/dataisbeautiful/
  • https://awesome-r.com/
  • http://www.htmlwidgets.org/showcase_leaflet.html
  • Overview of data sources here
  • DrivenData
  • CrowDanalytix
  • Kaggle
  • Tunedit
